Toys R Us Plans to Hire Fewer Holiday Season Workers

Toys R Us announced that it will not be hiring as many holiday season employees as last year, but the toy and baby products manufacturer said it will give its current employees and seasonal workers more working opportunities.
The company said it plans to hire 40,000 people at stores and distribution centers across the country, up from 45,000 last holiday season.
Many of the jobs will be part time.
The company said that interviews with candidates would start within this month and the number of personnel would increase from October to December.

Although the holiday season is still months away, the holiday shopping season is approaching and companies are gearing up to hire seasonal workers to help outfit their stores, sell, ship, and distribute products.
Michael J. Fox jokes about his "relationship" with Princess Diana.
The premiere of Back to the Future was a very important moment for Michael J. Fox.
It was also very important for personal reasons.

He describes this in the trailer of Back in Time, a documentary to be released soon as follows: "I was waiting for the members of the Royal Family to come to the cinema and I noticed that the seat next to me was empty and I realized that Princess Diana would sit there.
The movie started, and I realized that I was just a false stretch and arm's length away from dating the Princess of Wales.

Back in Time, a documentary about the movie Back to the Future, includes interviews with Fox, Lea Thompson, and Christopher Lloyd, as well as director Robert Zemeckis and executive producer Steven Spielberg.
Back to the Future had its premiere 30 years ago.
Spielberg said that "This is, for me, the most exciting time-travel movie ever made."
In addition to being available for VOD and DVD, Back in Time will also be screened in some select cinemas.
UN Başkanı Suriye'de Askeri Bir Çözümün Olmadığını Söylüyor

Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said the Syria problem, which has been going on for almost five years, cannot be solved with the military intervention and more weapons will only bring more violence and more pain to millions of people.
The Secretary-General also called upon all parties, including the divided Security Council, to come together to engage in constructive dialogue towards a political solution to the crisis.

Ban said he plans to meet with the foreign ministers of the five permanent council members -- the US, China, Russia, Britain and France -- in the run-up to the General Assembly meeting later this month.
The council said it was deeply concerned that divisions among council members and the Syrian people have rendered the situation "unsolvable" by regional powers.
Ban also called on the five permanent members to be united in the Syrian crisis as they were in the Iranian nuclear deal.
8 Poll Numbers That Show Donald Trump Is for Real
Some tried to label him as a volcano.
The others laughed at him.
And some are backing the idea of an internal explosion.
Some of the Republicans have been trying to drag Donald Trump down in the polls, but that has not worked (yet).
His latest 11 national polls show him double-digits ahead of Donald Trump, and some are starting to ask seriously about the real-estate mogul's chances of running.
It is of course still early in the election cycle.
None of these means that Trump can win the Republican nomination.
Experts say that in 2011, during these periods, Rick Perry's rise also caused Herman Cain to rise and both of them could not win the nomination process even in a single state.
And, there are many reasons why he is going to have trouble in the general election.
But outside groups such as Jeb Bush's Super PAC and the economic conservative group Club for Growth realize that Trump is for real and start spending their dollars to defeat him.
Here are some recent survey results that show that the property baron was not just a fly-by-night:
The probability of Trump's election has changed by 180 degrees.
A survey taken just before Trump announced his candidacy in mid-June by Monmouth University showed that just two of the 10 Republicans polled had a favorable view of the real-estate magnate.
By the middle of July, this rate was at forty percent.
It was 52 percent in early August.
Now, six out of ten Republicans have a positive view of Donald Trump.
Roughly ten percent of the population expresses a negative view.
And these numbers are high in the early stage.
A poll from last week in Iowa from Quinnipiac showed that 60 percent of Republicans there favor Donald Trump.
Two-thirds of GOP voters may not be satisfied with Trump's candidacy.
In a CNN/ORC poll released last week, 67 percent of Republicans said they would be “excited” or “satisfied” if Mr. Trump were the party’s nominee.
If he runs, only two people in the poll of 10 said they would be upset.
Only Ben Carson matches Trump in generating enthusiasm (40 percent characterize themselves as "enthusiastic" about Carson, compared to 43 percent for Trump.)
Who is the closest to excitement?
Marco Rubio, at only 21 percent.
On the other hand, 47 percent of Republican voters say they would be "disappointed" or "upset" if the party's favorite, Jeb Bush, were to run.
Most Republicans don't see Trump's temperament as a problem.

While Donald Trump is criticized for his grandiloquent language and put-downs, 52 percent of the Republicans polled by ABC News/Washington Post on Monday think the real estate tycoon has the right stuff to be president.

The same number applies in Iowa, where the first party convention will take place. There, according to a Quinnipac poll from last week, 52 percent of Republicans believe he has the personality to lead.
He still thinks that 44% of the population does not have an active personality and six out of ten independents say that his personality is not suitable for the White House, according to the ABC/Post.
Republican voters are beginning to get used to this idea.
When political experts put on their analyst hats, Republican voters think that Trump is a serious candidate.
According to a CNN/ORC poll conducted last week, four out of 10 people said that Trump was the best candidate to win the GOP nomination when asked who was the best candidate.
A shift from the end of July when four out of 10 put their money on Jeb Bush.
Full disclosure: The GOP crystal ball was not so clear in the past.
During the last election cycle, four in 10 Republicans thought Rick Perry would be their nominee, while only 28 percent chose Mitt Romney, who eventually became the nominee.
It is still seen that the majority of GOP voters find Trump's election campaign plausible.
Even if Republicans coalesce around another candidate, Trump still beats almost everyone.
Some experts also point to the fragmented nature of the field as a possible factor for Trump's emergence, and it is a fact that anti-Trump support is divided among a dozen or more candidates.
But a Monmouth University poll conducted in early September shows Trump winning the majority of votes in every possible match-up against a number of potential Republican candidates.
Cruz beats Carly Fiorina by 13 points, Marco Rubio by 14 points, Walker by 15 points, Jeb Bush by 19 points and finally Rand Paul, John Kasich and Chris Christie by 33 points.
A tie with Ted Cruz.
The only candidate who can beat him?
In a hypothetical head-to-head matchup, Ben Carson beats the businessman by 19 points.
The majority of Donald Trump's supporters say they have made up their minds.
A new CBS/NYT poll released on Tuesday showed that more than half of Trump-supporting voters say they have locked in their votes.
Frankly, a lot could happen to change this and no one can say for sure that nobody will change their mind.
46 percent say they would leave the door open to switching candidates.
Brain surgeon Ben Carson is still Trump's main rival, but voters who say they've made up their minds favor Trump by nearly a two-to-one margin.
Six out of ten Kemalists say that they are in agreement with Trump on the issue of immigration.

Since Donald Trump called for building a wall along the Mexican border and characterized undocumented immigrants from Mexico as "rapists" in his campaign announcement two months ago, immigration has been at the center of the 2016 conversation.
Some think that Trump's talk-too-much will push away the important Hispanic voters from the Republican Party and hurt the party's rebranding efforts.
But in a new ABC/ Post poll taken on Monday, six of 10 Republicans said they agreed with Trump on immigration.
So as long as immigration remains an issue, Trump seems to remain in the news.
The anger towards the government climbed to new heights.
Donald Trump and Ben Carson are roughly taking half of the Republican votes because of the states of affairs that are largely outside of the States.
In a new ABC News/Washington Post poll out Monday, six in 10 Republicans say they want someone from outside the government rather than someone with government experience.
And they're angry with Washington.

A Des Moines Register/Bloomberg poll in Iowa two weeks ago showed that three out of every four Republicans in Iowa was upset with Republicans in Congress, with 54 percent "dissatisfied" and 21 percent "extremely angry."
Jeremy Corbyn will take to the platform for the first time in Prime Minister's Questions.
Since the day he was elected, everyone was waiting eagerly for Mr. Corbyn’s appearance in the PMQs.
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will take Jeremy Corbyn will take to the despatch box in the House of Commons for the first time after David Cameron.
Mr. Corbyn will be due to ask six questions later in the day, and his performance is being closely watched by the media and Labor MPs.
In a weekly appearance on television, he called for 'less theatre, more reality'.
He also said he could skip some sessions, by leaving them over to his colleagues.
The meeting, which will be the first test of Mr Corbyn's leadership in Parliament, follows his shadow cabinet appointments and his speech to the TUC's annual conference on Tuesday.

Meanwhile, Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn's silence during a remembrance service on Tuesday to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain has also been criticized by some Tory MPs and is on the front pages of the newspapers.
Mr. Corbyn's decision not to sing the national anthem has drawn attention
A spokesman speaking on behalf of Mr Corbyn said he was standing in "respectful silence" and "acknowledged the heroism of the Royal Air Force in the Second World War".

However, Owen Smith, a member of Mr. Corbyn's shadow cabinet, told the BBC's Newsnight programme that he would advise the Labour leader to sing the national anthem "independently" of his belief that the monarchy should be abolished.

While around a dozen shadow cabinet members refused to serve in Mr. Corbyn's top team because of differences over economic, defence and foreign policy, less than a sixth of Labour MPs backed him as leader.
The BBC's political correspondent Robin Brant says splits are beginning to emerge within the Labour Party over Mr Corbyn's position on Brexit and the government's benefit cap.
Mr Corbyn said the Labour Party would set out new changes to abolish the upper limit completely at the TUC conference.
Hours later shadow work and pensions secretary Mr Smith said his party was only against the government cutting the upper limit from 26,000 £ to 23,000 £ and that he was "really clear" on that.
Mr Corbyn will be the fifth Labour leader to face David Cameron across the dispatch box since he became leader of the Conservative Party.
The Labour Party leader pledged a different approach to politics and said he had consulted “people power” and received more than 30,000 recommendations.
Islington North MP Jeremy Corbyn has said the program will be less confrontational and instead focus on issues like poverty, inequality and the challenges young people face.
Mr Corbyn revealed that in the absence of himself, for instance when Mr Cameron goes abroad, he would be represented by shadow trade minister Angela Eagle in Prime Minister's Questions.
At times, he even floated the idea that other colleagues could stand in the Speaker's chair, and he told the House of Commons Speaker John Bercow that he should consider it.

In 2005, when he became leader, Mr Cameron pledged to move away from the "Punch and Judy" style of politics associated with the Prime Minister's Questions; however, a few years later, he admitted failure in this respect.

Since its first broadcast in 1990, the weekly Question Time programme has been used as a benchmark for measuring leaders' decision-making abilities, their dominance in the House of Commons and the standing of their MPs, though some critics say it has been caricatured and that it needs major reform.

Joburg, a studio that teaches homeless youth how to earn income from taking pictures of their neighborhood.

Sterling rises as UK pay growth accelerates
Following data showing increased pay in the UK, the pound rallied as the FTSE 100 index also rose after a takeover bid for SABMiller.
In the United Kingdom, regular pay excluding bonuses rose 2.9% between May and July from the same period a year earlier.
This rate, which has been the fastest growing since 2009, is also seen as one of the leading indicators for possible interest rate increases.
The sterling gained more than a percent against the U.S. dollar and reached 1,5505 dollars and against the euro, it gained 0.84 percent and reached 1,3730 euros.
The FTSE 100 index increased by 1.49% to 6,229.21.
The most eye-catching company to rise in this period, was SABMiller, which added a 20% increase with its attractive acquisition offer from its competitor AB InBev.
The deal will combine two of the world's biggest beer companies and bring together such well-known brands as Budweiser, Stella Artois, Peroni and Grolsch.
Burberry shares rose 0.9 percent against a mixed European market as investors welcomed better-than-forecast profits from rival luxury group Richemont.
Richemont's recent sales figures show not only that sales are above expectations, but also that sales in China, a key market for Burberry, are again increasing.
Shares of mining giant Glencore surged 5% after the company said it raised $2.5 billion from a share sale as part of its strategy to reduce debt.
Mondi, the packaging and paper group, was among the biggest fallers after Goldman Sachs cut its recommendation on the shares from "neutral" to "sell".
Shares in JD Sports rose by 3.1 per cent after the retailer said its pre-tax profit rose 83 per cent to £46.6m over the six months to August.
The boss of JD Sports said higher wages could damage expansion.
JD Sports Chairman Peter Cowgill said the higher minimum wage in Britain could mean "more spending power in the pockets of potential customers”.
But he said this spending power would not be enough to cover his own high staff costs at his company.
He also added that the costs will affect JD Sports' expansion plans and could mean less extra work.
Metcash launches public campaign to fight off Aldi's invasion
Metcash is trying to protect its IGA stores in South Australia and Western Australia from an Aldi attack.
Market wholesaler Metcash has launched a public campaign to protect its retail stores in South Australia and Western Australia against a $700m Aldi invasion.

As Aldi prepares to open its first stores in South Australia and Western Australia next year and its store numbers will reach 120, Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening their relationships with local food suppliers and trying to build the IGA brand with mainstream and social media marketing and events, such as the Adelaide show.

IGA retailers and suppliers are also contributing, with brands such as Simmo, the Dunsborough-based ice-cream manufacturer which produces tastings at IGA stores, and store owners such as the South Australian football league who are offering discounted tickets to loyal customers.
Food, booze and hardware wholesaler Metcash is expected to deliver more detail on its defence strategy at its annual investor day on September 29.

The risk is great, since South Australia and Western Australia represent almost 30 percent of Metcash's IGA footprint and produce higher profit margins than Metcash's IGA network in the eastern states.

South Australian and West Australian store owners negatively view the narrow-minded IGA retailers in NSW, Victoria and Queensland, who enjoy a much stronger market share than they do in the east; 30% more in SA and 24% more in WA.

However, analysts such as Morgan Stanley believe that within 12 months of opening its first stores in these two states, Aldi will have captured approximately five percent of the grocery market, taking sales from existing players but, more generally, from independent retailers.
In a report released this week, Morgan Stanley analyst Tom Kierath forecast IGA retailers will lose $360 million over the next year and Metcash $250 million by the end of 2016.
That estimate is based on a projection that Aldi will open 25 stores in GA next year and 30 in BA, with each market generating $500 million and $600 million in sales, respectively.
Mr. Kierath, the loss of food and grocery sales as well as Metcash's high fixed cost base, could result in an EBIT of around $13 million for Metcash, he said.
Despite recent Roy Morgan research showing that IGA customers are the most loyal customers, Metcash is losing market share in the eastern states, mainly to ALDI and Coles.
According to Morgan Stanley, Metcash's food and grocery sales are expected to fall 3.8% in 2016, 4.1% in 2017 and 2.1% in 2018, which would take its market share from 14% in 2015 to 10.3% in 2020.
Last week, Hamish Douglass, the founder and lead fund manager of Magellan Financial Group, said at a business dinner in Melbourne that Metcash would "most likely be extinct in 10 years".
Metcash declined to respond to Mr. Douglass's comments.
But a Metcash board member is believed to have contacted Mr Douglass as recently as last week.

IGA's market share has fallen from 18 per cent to 14 per cent since 2010 and Metcash's earnings from its food and grocery business, which supplies about 1200 IGA retailers, have fallen 43 per cent since 2012, when sales and margins came under pressure, indicating a tightening of operating leverage.

But the wholesaler is fighting back, spending more than 150 million dollars a year on matching shelf prices for hundreds of products every week at Coles and Woolworths, helping IGA retailers refurbish their stores, adding faster-growing fresh foods and rolling out a better private-label grocery range.

Metcash Chairman Ian Morrice says the wholesaler's price matching and store improvement programs are starting to pay off and it expects to return to core earnings growth for the first time in four years in 2017.
Thanasi Kokkinakis is supported by Tennis Australia president Steve Healy
Thanasi Kokkinakis deserves much more credit than criticism for his behavior.
According to Tennis Australia President Steve Healy, Thanasi Kokkinakis was innocent in the last storm that broke out around his friend Nick Kyrgios and deserved much praise rather than criticism.

Young member of the "Special K's", normally called "Special K's" the talented pair Kokkinakis found himself under the spot lights that did not welcome him well because of Kyrgios' humiliating victory against Stan Wawrinka in the Montreal Masters.

In a tough qualifying match played in Cincinnati on the afternoon, Kokkinakis and his opponent Ryan Harrison were separated by the chair umpire twice, and Harrison made the following statement: "Wawrinka went in Kyrgios' face, and I have to go in that kid's face."
Kokkinakis, who was last seen at the US Open potentially ruining Richard Gasquet's day by snapping his racket, was staunchly defended by Healy.
The young player is currently in Glasgow competing in the Davis Cup semi-final against Britain with Sam Groth behind Bernard Tomic in the second singles role.
Healy said, "What I felt very strongly was that I was a little bit being drawn into the discussion by Thanasi."
After his run in the US was cut short and he lost his racquet, he did break it, but he wasn't the first player to do so in frustration, and I know Thanasi is aware that he shouldn't be proud of this.
In reality, Harrison dealt with himself quite well in the very provocative circumstances with the others in the United States. And, I think he deserves a lot of praises.
He has a fantastic team, a fantastic family around him and I think it has been a little bit overdone.

Despite his age of 19, he is very mature and works a lot, he adapts to the team, and he has no problem with the other players, is very respected in the locker room, he has very difficult training, he is very balanced and mature, and in my opinion, he deserves to be judged by his own standards.

Healy also supported the decision to welcome Kyrgios back into the fold, beginning on Friday, saying that the right thing to do for everyone was to "agree mutually", but to support the Canberran to come back to the team as an iron horse in the long term.
"First and foremost, we want the team to focus on the game, not the controversy surrounding Kyrgios," Healy said.

And I think, as Nick, Federer and Murray have all said, is that the kid was rising so fast, growing up in front of the public, and making some awful mistakes, and he's taken a lot of criticism that he deserves, but we're trying to support him, trying to help him understand the consequences of his actions, and sometimes when he's not under the spotlights, we think deeply about what's right for him, the team and himself.
The European migrant crisis: Hungary has declared a state of emergency, closed its borders, and put the migrants under arrest.
Hungary declared a state of emergency on Tuesday in order to cut the flow of migrants and closed its southern border with Serbia, detaining those trying to enter the country illegally.
Chaos erupted at the border, with hundreds of migrants clustering in a no-man's land and Serbian authorities reacting with anger.
The immigrants, who fled from the violence in their country, set up tents by the road and settled in these tents for an uncertain period of time between the control points of the two countries.
But the anger was growing.
As a police helicopter passed overhead, migrants shouted, "Open the border!" and hurled insults at the Hungarian riot police.
Some rejected the water and food that was given to them in protest.
The Serbian Foreign Minister said that Hungary's pushing back of migrants is "unacceptable" while the migrant flow from Macedonia and Greece continues.
(Serbia) does not want to be a victim of the process, it wants to be part of the solution.
Ivica Dacic said that he would have to talk with Brussels and other countries in the coming days.
The tension at the Hungary-Serbia border came a day after the bloc of 28 nations failed to agree on a common approach toward migrants at their meeting in Brussels.

The ministers reached agreement on sharing responsibility for the 40,000 migrants who have stormed into Greece and Italy and said they were hopeful of a deal at a summit next month for accepting another 120,000 migrants to EU countries, including Hungary.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria called for an EU summit on the migrant crisis facing the continent next week.
Hungary, however, is not too hopeful that Brussels or its neighbours will take any concrete steps on the matter.
A state of emergency declared in the two southern provinces on Tuesday gives officials broad powers to deal with the crisis, including closing roads as needed and speeding up migrant-related cases.

On the other hand, Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said Hungary planned to put up a fence on its border with Romania, like the one it built on its Serbia border, to stop migration from this country.
CBS News correspondent Charlie D'Agata reports that even prisoners are being enlisted in the effort to build a razor-wire fence between Hungary and Serbia.

In the last few months, Hungary has become the important bottleneck and transit point to the European Union countries, and most of these immigrants are refugees fleeing the wars in Syria and other Middle Eastern countries.

Prime Minister Viktor Orban is adamant that the greatest part of the incoming migrants are not innocent people escaping war, but rather "economic migrants" trying to get to Europe for a better life - a view that is in complete contrast to the views of other EU countries, including Germany.

The laws, which came into force at midnight in Hungary, also bring harsher penalties for people smugglers, in addition to making it a crime to attempt to cross or damage the four-meter (13-foot) tall razor-wire fence built along the Serbian border.

In Szeged in the south of the country, the government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs told reporters: "The Hungarian government is declaring a state of emergency due to the situation caused by the mass migration."
We are very clear on one thing; cross-border crime is a crime.
While the deployment of the soldiers has yet to be approved by parliament, Associated Press reporters in the area have reported seeing heavily armed soldiers with dogs and vehicles in the area.
Orban's domestic security advisor Gyorgy Bakondi said that the authorities had captured 45 people who had tried to cross the border, and 15 people had crossed the border and entered the country.
They crossed the wires at their own peril, and now, under police supervision and facing new laws, they are charged with committing a crime.
The authorities are quickly repairing the barbed wire.
Hungarian officials also closed two of its seven border crossings with Serbia on Tuesday morning, and used a barbed wire-covered train car to block one of the crossings.
With Hungarians introducing a small metal container which people are crammed into to get processed, chaos spread to the main border crossing at Roszke, near the border.
Though 20 people were able to get in, thousands were left outside.
Another group of migrants said that they had blocked a road linking Serbia and Hungary and would not accept food or water until they are allowed to enter Hungary.
Election 2016: Hillary Clinton's lead over Bernie Sanders halves in National Poll
Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is continuing her double-digit lead in the Democratic race for the presidential nomination, but Sen. Bernie Sanders is closing in.
Clinton is now at 47% of Democratic votes (at 58%), while Sanders is at the second place (27%, compared to 17%).
Vice President Joe Biden, who has not yet announced whether he intends to run for president, is polling at 15% of the Democratic vote.
Prior to the start of the early primaries, most Democratic voters said it was too early to decide which candidate to back.
Still, Clinton’s supporters have a stronger idea about their own vote than the others.
Since last month's CBS News poll, Clinton has lost ground among a number of demographic groups, while Sanders has made some gains.
Clinton is leading by a large margin among women and moderates but this margin is closing.
Support among men has fallen dramatically, and Sanders trails by just 5 points.
Clinton's advantage among Democrat voters under the age of 50 evaporated and she and Sanders are now in a dead heat.
But Clinton has a large advantage among the old voters.
Last month Clinton was leading Sanders by two digits among liberals, but now Sanders has a 5 point edge in this group.
The national survey of Democratic voters indicates that about half say they would enthusiastically support Clinton if she were the party's nominee.
A quarter of the party supporters would support him under certain conditions, while another 15 percent would back him only if he were the candidate.
Six percent of the voters do not support Clinton.
Perhaps not surprisingly, Clinton's current supporters are especially inclined to back her enthusiastically.
The views among those who don't currently support Clinton are even more mixed - just a quarter can muster passionate support for her.
It talks about Republican front-runners, with 48 percent of Democrats saying they will passionately support Clinton and 35 percent saying they will support Trump.

When supporters of Clinton were asked open-ended questions about why they wanted Clinton to run, the top responses were that she has the experience (16 percent), it's time to elect a woman president (13 percent), and she is the best choice for the job (10 percent).
Clinton's supporters also cite her relationship with Bill Clinton (9 percent).
Being conciliatory in conflict and being electable are among the criteria listed.
As a Vice President with potential to run for the Presidency, 57 percent of Democrat voters might want to see her in the race, but nearly one-third of the public does not agree.
When asked who Democratic voters want as the party's second choice in the primaries, Biden is at the top.
More than half of Clinton's supporters say Biden would be her clear second choice, according to Sanders.
If Biden doesn't run, Hillary Clinton's lead over Sanders increases; with Biden in the race, she leads by 20 points, without Biden she leads by 30.
Fifty-five percent of Democratic voters say Clinton is the most electable candidate; that figure was at 78 percent last month.
Biden, in this sense, is well behind, even though he is second, but the percentage of those who see him as the most electable candidate has increased.
When asked what the most important thing is about a candidate, the Democratic voters rank issues ahead of electability.
As similar to the last month, no Democratic voter candidate or candidate candidate seems to be accepted as a candidate for these primary voters.
Democratic candidates or potential candidates perform well among their party's primary voters in some key characteristics.
Majorities view Clinton, Sanders and Biden as honest and trustworthy, as well as having strong leadership qualities.
Of the three, Biden is ranked first in terms of honesty, and Clinton is strong in terms of leadership.
Thirty percent of Democratic voters say Clinton is not honest or trustworthy, and half as many (15 percent) say the same about Sanders, while 27 percent have no opinion.
Democratic voters also generally see Clinton, Sanders and Biden as in line with their ideology.
There's a quarter of Democratic voters who don't have an opinion about Sanders on all measures.

While questions continue about her use of a personal e-mail address and server while at the state department, most Democratic voters find her explanation on the matter satisfactory and say it has not affected their view of her.
But it’s a different story in the wider American public.
While half of Americans are now dissatisfied with his explanations, only three in ten find them satisfactory.
The views of the public on this issue divided shortly after the matter was brought under public scrutiny in March.
Most Americans say the email controversy did not change their overall opinion of Clinton, while 36 percent say it made them feel more negatively.
These are generally Republicans, and more than six in ten say their view of Clinton has been damaged.

While Clinton is regarded as honest and trustworthy by voters of her own party, this issue still remains a problem among registered voters in general: only 32 percent of them are seeing her as honest and trustworthy, which is eight points less from last month and 15 points less from May.
Sixty-two percent of registered voters do not find him honest and trustworthy.
At the same time, 55 percent of registered voters across the country also find Trump dishonest and untrustworthy.
However, both Clinton and Trump receive good grades in leadership.
Of the six contestants who took part in the test, Biden, Carson and Bush received the highest scores on honesty.
More of them find Sanders honest, but most are not yet sold on him, as they are on Carson.
The margin of error for the sample of 351 Democratic voters is plus or minus 6 percentage points.
Ben Carson is right behind Donald Trump in national polls
According to the latest CBS News/New York Times poll, Ben Carson is running a close second to Donald Trump
The new poll shows that the voters of two candidates make up about half of the votes, and the other candidates do not have much of a chance.

Republican voters across the country continue to support Trump by large numbers, with the latest CBS poll released Tuesday showing his support rising from 23 percent before the debate on Fox News last month to 27 percent.
But, Carson's support jumped from 6% to 23% during the same time period.
The poll also found that Carson did very well with demographic groups, with support among college-educated Republican voters much higher than Trump.
The rest, except for Carly Fiorina and Ohio Governor John Kasich, have dropped from 10% support last month to 2%.
Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, and Florida Senator Marco Rubio are in third place with 6 percent each.
The sample of 376 Republican primary voters was drawn from a larger sample of 1,099 registered voters with a margin of error of plus or minus 6 percentage points and was conducted in September.
A new CNN/ORC poll released last week shows that Carson's support among Republicans has risen to 19%, putting him in second place just behind Trump's 32% support.
The latest poll by ABC News/Washington Post shows Trump with a serious edge over Carson.
Trump, who found himself up against Carson's rise last week, apologized to the retired brain surgeon for questioning his faith, but continued to randomly poke him.
At a campaign stop in Iowa on Saturday, Trump said, "We need energy."
Five fraternity members charged in death of Baruch College freshman
Nearly two years after a college student died during a fraternity pledge ceremony in the Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania, five people have been charged with murder.

The New York City Baruch College Pi Delta Psi fraternity savagely beat Chun "Michael" Deng during a pledge initiation ceremony in September 2013 and, according to police, contributed to his death by delaying taking him to the hospital.
Authorities said his eyes were blindfolded, a 30 pound sand bag was attached to his back, and he was continuously tripping as he attempted to walk across the frozen field to his target.
Mr. Deng stated that his head hurt and later lost his consciousness and filed a complaint.
Members of the Pi Delta Psi fraternity did not call 911 after Deng fell ill and waited an hour to take him to the hospital, according to police.

However, according to the Police Commissioner Chris Wagner, who spoke at the press conference, they changed Deng's clothes, searched for symptoms on Google and contacted the national chairman of the sorority, Andy Meng, to ask for advice.
Kommissar Wagner said that at this point the members started putting their personal belongings and their own interests before the welfare of the brotherhood, which was a very bad thing.
He could not be revived and died the next morning.
According to an autopsy report, Deng suffered trauma caused by repeated blunt blows to the head, torso, and buttock.

Douglas Fierberg, an attorney who represents Deng's family, said in a statement that “As a result of fraternity hazing, many families have been devastated, and at least one student has died each year as a result of fraternity hazing activities since 1970.”
Fraternities and their members should be held responsible for this and it’s important that officials take this step.
The grand jury of Monroe County recommended that criminal charges of third-degree murder be filed against the first five members.
Thirty-two members of the brotherhood, including Mr. Meng, will face criminal proceedings for conspiracy to commit an attack.
Wagner, in a news conference on Tuesday, said that we will also hold responsible the organizations that officially or unofficially approved of this.
Baruch College banned the fraternity and the national fraternity severed ties with the local chapter.
What will happen if the Fed increases the interest rates?
Due to the increase in interest rates, bull market is reversed and the income of bonds rises, while the economy also records a recession.
We know that.
What we do not know is how long it will take and how long it will last.
History, especially in economics, offers very little information about timing.
Contractions, too, have varied in length from the shortest, 11 months after the first rate increase, to the longest, 86 months.
The aggressive stance of the US Federal Reserve in raising the interest rates has been dominant, albeit not always, in the reaction of the economy and financial assets.
That is why Fed officials have stressed that investors should focus not on when interest rates will begin to rise but on how long the normalization will take.
It is a fact that there are various variables.
However, market participants could think that the hike hype has been exaggerated.

In a note to clients, Julian Jessop, global chief economist at Capital Economics, said, "It is inevitable that the Fed's first interest rate rise since the global financial crisis is viewed by some as a sign the era of cheap money is coming to an end."
Contrary to this, we don't expect the US interest rates to return to a more normal level soon, but it has been seen that most of the levels that are still low are the seismic shock that frightened.
Still, we cannot say that it will not have any effects.
Based on past trends, the reaction that some parts of the economy may give could be as follows:
As in the past few months, waiting for interest rates to be increased can unbalance some things temporarily.
There is not such a dramatic effect when interest rates are increased.

In a new research on the effects of the rate hikes, Deutsche Bank analysts say, "It is observed that the returns on equity tend to pause for 12 to 24 months after the first rate hike, which may reflect the pause in monetary policy."

According to a recent analysis shared by Bob Doll, analyst at Nuveen Asset Management, in the Barron’s, the market mostly tends to see sharp rises around 250 days after the rate hike (an average of 14 percent) and head steadily toward a rate hike in the next 250 days (an average of 2.6 percent increase) and after 500 days, it returns to normality and makes an average return of 14.4 percent in the last six cycles.
Deutsche said the impact on earnings is likely to become more pronounced in the later stages of the rate-hike cycle.
Setbacks are a fact of life in the economic world, but interest rate increases help them.
The Fed is currently facing some situations it has not experienced before, which could worsen the recession.
Most noteworthy is the gap between the Fed's rate increase and the gross domestic product, which remains at its lowest level for today.
According to Deutsche Bank, over the 118 interest rate hikes since 1950, nominal year-over-year gross domestic product has been below 4.5 percent just twice.
Even though the second quarter of 2015 has seen the real GDP at the level of 3.6% the Atlanta Fed sees this as not lasting; the third quarter is now being seen at 1.5%.
According to Deutsche, raising interest rates at such a sensitive economic time could be risky and could raise the question of "whether this time will be different."
The attention of market participants who have been waiting for a year for the Fed to raise rates will be on the Federal Open Market Committee meeting this week, which will end on Thursday.
While most strategists and economists believe the FOMC could approve a rise at this meeting, futures trading is pointing to only a 25 percent probability.

The report stated that "our research shows that all of the expansion cycles since 1950 have been superimposed on a rising trend, and that gross domestic product, after an initial recovery, is poised to quickly reach the peaks reached prior to the downturn."
On the contrary, this has been a recovery in the slowest pace of growth on record in a period of exemplary stability.
The current cycle is the longest that the Fed has waited since the last recession - the longest cycle on record was 35 months, and the current cycle is now 74 months and counting.
With the expectation of interest rate increase in the market, the fixed income is becoming more unstable and it resembles our equity a bit.
The big difference is that the effect will be seen more quickly in equities than bonds when Fed policy changes direction.
When the first increase/decrease of the cycle occurs, bond yields do not change direction immediately.
In the end of the rate-hike cycle, bond yields fall immediately," Deutsche said.
Charles Schwab strategists see the rise in rates as flattening the yield curve by bringing yields on longer and shorter term bonds closer together.

Kathy Jones, one of the analysts at Schwab, says that in general we say that higher-yielding bonds have performed better in this kind of environment, but we are still cautious in terms of getting to the returns.
Interestingly, Jones thinks the markets have already adapted to the Fed's policy expectations.
"In addition to the dollar's strength and the drop in inflation expectations, there are various signals of a market that is adjusting to tighter monetary policy," he wrote.

Short-term interest rates are going up, the yield curve is flattening, credit spreads are widening, and volatility is increasing - all characteristics that should be expected in the market when the FED tightens policy.

Looking at the bigger picture, companies that do most of their business in the United States will probably make up for their losses by raising their interest rates and making the local products more desirable.

The situation of the heavily indebted multinational companies will be worse as the increasing dollar will make their products more expensive in the global market and their debts will be more expensive.
In a report prepared for clients, Goldman Sachs analysts wrote "History shows that 'quality' stocks can underperform at the start of such a run,"
Companies with strong balance sheets had outperformed those with weaker balance sheets by an average of 5 percent after rate increases in 1994, 1999 and 2004.
Companies with stocks of high capitalization and low volatility also outperformed their low-quality competitors, with a mean of 3-4 percent.
Debts will become a big issue.
According to Goldman, the companies with the biggest exposure to foreign-currency debt are the ones most likely to take the biggest hits.
In addition to a pure gambling, shoppers are expected to benefit from the growing dollar.
While experts are divided on how fast they should go, savers can also profit from higher gains.
Andrew Bingham told BBC Radio 3's Classic FM that
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham accused the station of "going downmarket."
He argued that radio increasingly resembled the commercial broadcasters.
She also accused the BBC Music Awards of aiming and undermining the Brit Awards.
His colleague Damien Collins accused The Voice of being unoriginal.
A prominent MP has put pressure on the broadcaster by saying that BBC Radio 3 is becoming more and more like Classic FM in order to highlight its differences from the other commercial stations.
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham said BBC radio channels, which provide a public service, were "going downmarket" and were increasingly indistinguishable from their commercial rivals.
He said, "I don't like to use this term, but Radio 3 is becoming 'popularized' and is turning into a classic FM station."
In addition, it targeted the first BBC Music Awards, which were held last December.
The BBC Music Awards, which were launched last year, is yet another version of the Brit Awards.
"If you're trying to do something different, those are the first two examples that come to mind, but you just copy what's already out there," Bingham said.
The general manager of the BBC rejected the accusations and defended that BBC Radio 3 is by far ahead of its commercial rivals in both live music and public education.
If I am learning from Radio 3, I don't go and learn something else about classical music from somewhere else.
And that is devotion to live music and making music can't be compared to any other thing.
He also said that he thought Radio 3's efforts to discover new music and present performances were very important.

Alan Davey, manager of BBC Radio 3, claimed at the beginning of the year that the radio needs to work more than in the past to reach more listeners, because British people are less educated in the field of classical music.
But the BBC Radio 3, Arts, Media & Sport Select Committee meeting was not the only component of the BBC to get a kicking for hogging the queue ahead of its commercial rivals.

Tory MP Damien Collins also took a swipe at The Voice - the BBC's music talent show, which it has bought the rights to from Dutch production company Talpa Media for £22m - for not offering enough value for money.
Can't you see why this program is so popular, because it is not original, and doesn't have any special features.
Lord Hall insisted that the BBC1 show, which is judged by Paloma Faith and Boy George, is being made in a "uniquely BBC style".
He said that the channel should find a hit of its own before broadcasting an entertainment program again.
However, he did not accept the idea of blocking the production of more The Voice programs in the future, or spending the money on other formats.
Is it the Black Friday that caused the lowest increase in August internet sales in history?
In the first three months of 2015, there was a 7% increase in online sales.
Last month, the lowest growth was recorded since 2000, where records began to be broken.
When mobile devices began being used in shopping three years ago, an explosion occurred in online sales.
Experts point out that Black Friday in November could be the reason for decreased spending.
Shopping online has been exploding for more than a decade, taking a ghost town out of some of Britain's liveliest shopping streets.
After numbers showed that in the first three months of 2015, there was only a 7% increase in internet sales, experts pointed out that internet sales are increasingly showing signs of weakness.
The total amount of spending in August increased only by five percent compared to the same period last year and this is the lowest growth since 2000 when records began.
Experts say that after the figures show that internet sales have only increased by 7% in the first three months of 2015, internet sales are showing more and more signs of weakening.

Andy Mulcahy, the sales index editor at IMRG, told the Guardian that "when you look at the levels of growth in previous years and particularly in 2000, you can see that everything has returned to normal over time."
He also added that internet sales have increased a lot since three years ago, when consumers began to use their cell phones to purchase products.
This meant that more people would be able to shop while stretched out in an armchair.
But we are at a plateau now, you can see the dip.
The phenomenon of Black Friday, which was imported from America, is being used as one of the reasons for the slowdown in sales.
Experts point out that consumers may be waiting for this event, which takes place on the last Friday of November, to make purchases.
Last year's event saw five times more consumers than the previous year swarm to retailers' websites for a bargain, causing many sites to crash.
Experts say that the Black Friday shoppers, who were seen fighting over discounts, "could be tamed" for now.
A study conducted by the British Retail Consortium revealed that for every five pounds spent on shopping, one pound is spent on buying goods from the internet.
One third of certain items such as TVs and washing machines are now being purchased from internet stores.
Also more than a quarter of the people buy their clothes and shoes from the internet instead of the luxury and showy shopping streets.
Muslims bid farewell to the victims of the crane accident in Mecca, where Bin Laden family was found guilty.
After the first funerals in Mecca, the bodies of the 29 people who lost their lives were carried on the streets by Muslims.
Saudi Arabia held construction giant Saudi Binladin Group responsible for the crane accident that took place in Medina.
The ministry of health reported that a total of 394 people were injured after the crane collapsed.
Hundreds of Muslims came together to carry the bodies of 29 people who lost their lives when a crane collapsed in the Grand Mosque.
The majority of the crowd inside, the whites, blocked the roads to bid farewell to the last journeys of the first funerals at the Muaysim Cemetery in Mecca.
The mourners passed by the holy site where the disaster occurred, in which the ceiling of a mosque collapsed a few days ago and fell on the pilgrims.
In addition to the 394 wounded, the dead bodies were brought to be buried after Saudi Arabia held the Binladen family, the owner of the construction holding responsible for the incident.
The bodies of 29 pilgrims who died when a crane fell in the Grand Mosque were carried on shoulders along the road
There were four fathers from the Bolton area of Manchester, one of whom was Kasim Akram, taking his first hajj when the crane crashed among the dead.
Mr. Akram had come to the Holy Mosque with his mother and father at the beginning of the Hajj pilgrimage.
Saudi leaders announced that the Hajj would continue with the participation of thousands of pilgrims on the road to Mecca.
In a statement today, King Salman said that the Binladin Holding Group should not have left the crane arm open while unused.
The Arabic version of the statement prepared by the Saudi Press Agency, operated by the government, said that Binladin Group was the only party that would be prosecuted for the incident.
The English service of the news agency did not mention this detail, but it told officials of the company that they are banned from traveling abroad.
On Monday, Salman swore that they would find the cause of the crane's collapse in the courtyard of the Grand Mosque in Mecca, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims arrive each month during the Hajj.
Binladin group did not make any statement about the collapsed crane and did not allow their representatives to make comments.
The royal decree accused the group of failing to take current security measures and not cooperating with meteorology officials.
The Grand Mosque in Mecca is surrounded by dozens of cranes, much of the construction being under the management of the Binladen Group.
The bin Laden family has long been close to the ruling family of Saudi Arabia, and is behind many of the construction projects.
Al Qaeda's last leader Osama Bin Laden was also the family's disinherited son.

And of course David Cameron would know The Lorax better than that?
This is something that every parent learns in a short time: when your child loves a book, you know that it will not take long for you to memorize it almost by heart.

In Thneed-Ville, a city enclosed by walls and where the entire nature and even air are commodities, a boy named Ted wants to fulfill his love Audrey's desire to see a real tree to win her heart, writes the screenplay writer Audrey Geisel, the widow of Dr. Seuss, who has integrated an unknown love story of Dr. Seuss, whose real name was Theodor Seuss Geisel, into the story.

Experts criticize an e-cigarette research conducted by Public Health England.

Researchers highlighted the proposals of e-cigarettes, saying that they are 95 percent less harmful than smoking at a meeting of 12 people, with links to the tobacco industry, held by an agency funded by the government.
In an article in the British Medical Journal, the experts joined Lancet in criticizing the evidence used in a report on e-cigarettes by England's Public Health.
PHE published its "landmark" report, which it describes as a "thorough examination of the evidence", last month.
But some researchers have questioned the data's validity and drawn attention to ties between some experts and the tobacco industry.
The Lancet medical journal's lead editorial last month targeted PHE's "extraordinarily flimsy foundation" for its key findings.
The other two researchers, who wrote an article in the BMJ, questioned whether the claims were built on sand or rock.

Professor Martin McKee of the London School of Hygiene and Tropic Medicine and Professor Simon Capewell of the University of Liverpool said, "The central principle of public health is that policies should be based on evidence of effectiveness."
They said they expect PHE's claims that e-cigarettes are "around 95% less harmful than smoking" are based on a detailed examination of the evidence and modelling.

In fact, it is the product of a 12-person meeting convened to develop a multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) model to synthesize their thoughts on the harms of a variety of nicotine-containing products; the results of the meeting were summarized in a research paper.

McKee and Capewell reported that one of the sponsors of the conference was a company called EuroSwiss Health, whose CEO had previously received funding from British American Tobacco for an independent study.
They also said they approved the company's public health promotion certificate in a sustainability report.

They reported that one of the 12 people in this meeting had received funding from an e-cigarette manufacturer, but they also added that this was not the funding that had been reported to be received from the Philip Morris International tobacco company.
The information about how the panel members were selected is not given, but some of them reported industry funding for the e-cigarette, including some of the known giants, in the article.
Some others in attendance at the meeting are not known for their expertise on tobacco control.
A representative from PHE's Tobacco Control Unit attended the meeting.
McKee and Capewell acknowledge in the paper the group wrote that there is a "lack of clear evidence for the harms of most products on many criteria", despite them being "effectively" banned.
But none of these connections or restrictions are discussed in the PHE report.
McKee and Capewell said that claims that there was no evidence for e-cigarettes being a transition to smoking for children or non-smokers were premature.
In the PHE, the director of health and well-being Prof Kevin Fenton said that the claims in the BMJ were responded earlier.
He said, "E-cigarettes are significantly less harmful than smoking tobacco."
One out of two lifelong smokers dies because of his/her addiction.
All the evidence indicates that the health risks of e-cigarettes are comparatively small, but we need to continue to examine the long-term effects.
PHE has a clear mission: to inform the public, especially at a time of great confusion about the relative harms of tobacco, about what the evidence does and does not show.
About 80,000 people die each year from smoking-related illness and smoking costs the NHS £2 billion a year.

By clearly laying out the currently available evidence - that while e-cigarettes are not risk-free they carry only a fraction of the harm caused by smoking - we are fulfilling our national responsibility.

Johnson, a serial entrepreneur who ran Channel 4 from 2004 to 2010, blamed BBC for chasing ratings because of the "passion of the people who work here and the way that these people see that as the best way to guarantee long-term support."

Johnson said that more suitable public service programs of the BBC were now going to BBC4 and that they could not be measured by audience numbers but that they covered the cost of the tax exemption and the concessionary piety tasks that still continued to provide the grounds for 4 billion pounds of revenue from the license fee and added, "We are of course also doing all these stupid programs that no one watches."

About the license fee, Johnson told the committee this, "I invite you to find a system that is more regressive from the point of view of the people who benefit the most from it.

Also speaking to the committee on Tuesday, former Sky and Channel 5 executive David Elstein said the BBC should revise its Reithian mission to inform, educate and entertain.

The BBC's output is now officially classed as education - 1% of its television output and 0.1% of its radio output, he said - and public service broadcasters in Australia and Canada should lead the way and change this to "inform, enlighten and educate".

On partnerships, Elstein said that the BBC needs to find ways to do something with the Proms, which are only a handful of those on TV and make them available to be streamed online and do that in partnership with the advertising agencies.
‘Sonogenetics’ allows for brain cells to be controlled by sound waves.
The video shows how the spiders change their direction when they are hit by the sound vibrations.
Scientists grew maggot-like creatures with genetically modified nervous systems that can be controlled by sound waves.
The small threadworms change direction when they are hit by sound vibrations at a pitch that humans cannot hear.
They are operated by genetically modified motor nerve cells, which are activated by vibrations, which respond to ultrasound waves, and carry zebra channels.
Related: Researchers are reading and writing brain activity with light
The researchers said that the maggots proved the power of a new procedure called sonogenetics; thus, ultrasound can be used to activate a series of brain, heart and muscle cells outside the body.

Sreekanth Chalasani, a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, told the Guardian that one day the procedure could be replaced by an interventionist procedure that places electric vibrations inside people's brains to treat Parkinson's disease symptoms.
Silkworms don't normally respond to ultrasound, but Chalasani found they react when they are surrounded by a liquid containing microscopic bubbles.
The bubbles that it finds enhance audio frequency waves and help them pass through the ticks.
Amplified sound waves affect structures called TRP-4 ion channels that are found on membranes of some chigger cells.
According to a report published in Nature Communications, sound waves cause these ion channels to open, and therefore activate the cells to which they are connected.
To create the sonically controlled threadworms, Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons would carry TRP-4 ion channels.
When she applied ultrasound to the altered creatures, the sound waves were amplified by microbubbles, transmitted into the bugs and activated the altered motor neurons.
This procedure shares similarities with optogenetics, a revolutionary tool that enables scientists to turn neurons on and off with flashes of light.
But Chalasani says that sonogenetics has some advantages over this technique.

Unlike light, which has to be sent through an optical fiber to the desired point inside the brain, low-frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue without hindrance, and thus they can be sent into the brain through the skull.

Chalasani said, "We believe that using gene therapy and a therapeutic virus, we can make human neurons targeted for specific neurological therapies temporarily sensitive to ultrasound in the clinical environment."
He added that other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells.

Eight golden rules for being a student in a dormitory.

I moved into student halls 11 years ago as a nineteen-year-old with no idea, and I still believe in beanies and moral relativism, but now I remember the feigned smiles of those I disturbed - and the endless list of complaints about everyone else.
Most of what I have learned can be distilled into eight golden rules.
Moving back home can range from nerve-racking to completely terrifying.

The allure of chit-chat: Where are you from, did you lose a year, where did you insist on Corbyn and why, "I'm frankly Marmite, I don't love or hate it because it's really yeast extract HAHAHAH I'm going to be in my room."
Take a deep breath.
And let others have a turn - ask questions and show an interest.
This will help you to distinguish people that you like from the people that you would not like, even if your eyelashes were on fire and they had the extinguisher in their hands.
Give people a little space.
People's rooms frequently turn into drinking receptions, cinema evenings, and places to hang out, but they are also where people get dressed and adjust their underwear.
Related: Don't even think about starting university with a relationship
The introverts are badly treated at the university.
Your room may be your sanctuary, but most apartment building hallways create a culture of lingering, and this is friendly, social and open to life-long friendships.
This can be hell for someone trying to store energy.
In the culture, nothing allows you to say "I like you and want our friendship to continue, but I need some space so I can replenish the energy I spend communicating with you."
Try to sense when a friend is tired of socializing and perhaps text rather than call.
Speaking of knocking on doors, do so.
One of my friends at the dormitory had adopted a policy that if the door is not locked, anyone is invited in.
He has seen many things.
Make friends through cooking

At the peak of the cooking contest craze, from the time you start college, people will consider it less weird and less 1950s-"welcome to the neighborhood, I made you something, now smile while I ask you personal questions" to introduce yourself by knocking on doors with a plate of brownies.
Offering home-made delicacies to people is a great way to meet friends.
Your housemates will be forced to talk and they will probably associate your face with a sweet surprise.
To be honest, it's about your being a master chef.
A lumpy dough of flour, sugar, and fat that will cause people to pretend to be sleeping when you knock on their door.
Stealing food from student dormitories is a common crime.
To be honest, is it stealing to take someone's chicken but is it stealing to take a few drops of milk for your tea?
Check the owner of the milk twice.
He will very likely tell you to fend for yourself even when he is swimming in it.

It is very upsetting to have someone steal your things and I understand how you feel, but try to deal with it in a more mature way than my dorm mate. He punished the milk thief by pouring soap into the milk carton.
He is in prison now.
Do not make noise that prevents people from sleeping or studying.
That's not just being a decent human being, it's being an Ein person because you live in a glass house.
There is a girl on my corridor who went to her neighbour on the other side and asked her to turn the bass and drums down because it is 3 a.m. and she has an exam tomorrow.
The answers turned out to be turn it up.
Finally, at 5 am, when they closed the place, the girl turned up the volume of her music and locked the place, kindly allowing them to sleep for two hours before she went to her own three hour exam.
Wouldn't it be romantic if your future spouse was moved to the same corridor with you?

On the other hand, isn't it a little strange for you to misunderstand your corridor friend as your future spouse, to fall in love, to break up and having to see her every day and having to watch your common friends being enslaved?
Of course, follow your heart, but if you're convinced that your fiery neighbor is not your future spouse, at least talk to the young man and advise him to calm down.

In a playful moment, if you notice that someone has left their keys inside the house without locking the door, know that the line between having fun and doing injustice to someone is thinner than you think.
A good joke is entertaining, but it will take time to come back.
You can teach a valuable and fun lesson about security to someone by hiding their things, but never make someone's room dirty with shampoo and toothpaste.
Lock your doors and freeze your keys in a glass of water, but do not stick your belongings to the ceiling more than twice.

The oil companies are officially bankrupted.
From 2014, when oil prices began to fall, to the end of last year, about $400 billion worth of investment was deferred, with most of it from deepwater oil exploration projects.

According to a study by consultancy firm Wood Mackenzie, low oil prices have led to the deferral of $380 billion of oil and gas exploration/production projects and millions of barrels of production from the Gulf of Mexico to Africa has been delayed in a wide geography.

The report, which shows that oil prices have dropped seventy percent from one hundred and fifteen dollars in the summer of 2014 to the twelve year low in the last eighteen months, uses the expression "Company budgets have dramatically contracted" as the biggest reason for cost reductions.
400 BILLION DOLLARS IN BANK
As the price of crude oil makes new surprises every day, it has fallen below 30 dollars by seeing the lowest level of the last 12 years.

An analysis released by energy consultancy Wood Mackenzie as the debate on whether oil will fall to $15 or become cheaper than water heats up shows how the sector is being affected by the fall in prices.

In its latest report published in July, Wood Mackenzie shows that falling oil prices are putting $200 billion in investments from 46 major energy projects on hold. In its new research, Wood Mackenzie reveals how this number will grow until the end of 2015.
According to this, 22 major projects were postponed in the last six months of 2015, bringing the total number of major projects postponed since the start of the collapse of oil in 2014 to 68.
The value of these projects is around 400 billion.
2.9 million barrels a day
The research, highlighting the "harsh" impact of low oil prices on company plans, notes that the most affected projects are deep water development projects.
The suspended projects equate to 27 billion barrels of oil equivalent in reserve. This means that 2.9 million barrels of oil per day are postponed until 2025.
According to the research, the final investment decisions for most of the projects have been postponed until 2017 or later and the first production targets have been delayed to between 2020 and 2023.

The report, which underlined that 68 postponed projects include 170 billion dollars of potential investment planned to be made within the next five years, said, "The majority of 170 billion dollars is deep sea projects."
Another reason for this is that the initial investment costs are very high.
"Deep water expenditures make up 70% of the spending with Nigeria, Angola and US Gulf of Mexico oil-weighted projects leading the way."
According to the study, the countries with the highest inventory of deferred projects are Canada, Angola, Kazakhstan, Nigeria, Norway and the U.S.
These six countries are home to almost 90 percent of the world's proven (oil) reserves.
Mozambique, Australia, Malaysia and Indonesia which have the largest amount of delayed gas reserves, make up together approximately 85 percent of the total.

While the majority of the natural gas that is waiting to be released here is deep underwater, it requires complex and costly development solutions such as setting up a liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant from scratch.

It is mentioned that oil giants, which are the most exposed companies, have deep sea, Canadian oil sands and commitments in the Caspian region following one another, and it is also mentioned that the companies are trying to adapt to the "longer and lower" oil price scenario.
EYES ON IRAN

It was not long ago that the picture looked like this: The U.S. and Europe had imposed an embargo on Iranian oil to stop Iran's nuclear program, the price of oil was about 110 dollars a barrel, and the question was how to curtail Iran's oil exports without causing an abrupt spike in prices.
However, when we return to this week we see a very different scenario.
Oil prices fell below $30 for the first time since 2004, due primarily to a production boom in the U.S. and the lifting of sanctions against Iran.
For this reason, the eyes are on Iran.
If Iran improves its oil exports, then there will be even more oil flowing into the already saturated oil market.
That could cause prices to fall below levels that are surprising us today.
Some analysts say Saudi Arabia may pump even more oil to defend its market share against Iran, and there could be a price war between Iran and Saudi Arabia.
It is noted that once the sanctions are lifted, Iran's principal targets will be the rapidly growing oil market in Asia India and its former partners in Europe.
Iranian officials had previously said that they aimed at increasing exports by 500,000 barrels per day in the first phase, and then adding another 500,000 barrels to the market after a while.
At least 13 out of 22 very large crude carriers (VLCCs), or supertankers, are fully loaded or carrying significant cargoes, according to tracking data on Reuters.
Iran is in the position of a country with the world's fourth-largest proven petroleum reserves.
Through exemptions from the sanctions, Iran is still exporting about one million barrels of crude oil per day to some countries, including Turkey.
Before the sanctions, Iran's daily petroleum exports was up to three million barrels a day.

Support Securities Research Expert Aysun Göksu answers the question of whether oil will fall below 20 dollars as follows: "Global growth concerns centered on China increase the downward pressure on commodity prices, causing a deepening of losses in oil prices."

We are seeing that oil has dropped 20% since the beginning of the year, due to concerns that the demand for oil will decrease in China, which is the largest importer of oil in the world, parallel to the economic slowdown.
In addition, the global value increase of the dollar and the global excess supply problem will cause us to see the price of oil drop below $30 a barrel in the coming days.
As long as the prices do not remain above the levels of 32-33 dollars, the upward movement in oil may remain limited and the downward pressure may increase.
At this point, it can be said that the key role is to see the closing below the critical 30 dollars which would enable the declines to continue.
In such a case, it is not surprising to see retracements last as far as the 23.30-25.60 support zone on the downside.

Who is Bergen?
Bergen, whose real name is Belgin Sarilmiser, was born in Mersin on 16 July 1960.
His mother Sebahat Çakır moved to Ankara in 1966, following the divorce of his parents.

After the Yunus Emre Primary School in Yenimahalle, she entered the Piano department of the Ankara State Conservatory, but she left due to financial difficulties and worked at PTT for a while to mature her age.
He accepted a job offer he received after he went on stage at Feyman Night Club, where he had gone to have some fun with his friends in 1979.
Feyman performed Turkish classical music, Turkish light music and arrangements reflecting the fashion of the time in the group Lokomotif orchestra at the Feiman Night Club.
Bergen first met Halis Serbes in Adana, where she went for work after Ankara, and married him a year later.
In the year 1982, he released his first album, "Şikâyetim Var" from Atlas Plak.
Bergen, who could not stand the abuse by her husband, who was making progress in his art life, fled from her husband many times.
In October, 1982, when she was working in Izmir, someone threw acid in her face by the instigation of her husband.

Berg, who lost one eye and had large parts of her body burned in the attack, was convinced by Cengiz Özşeker, the composer of "Kimbilir", the song that made Kibariye famous after her treatment, to go on stage.

Performing on the stage of the Diamond Pavilion in Izmir, which was owned by Özşeker until 1985, the artist prepared a demo cassette named "We are Friends" (in Turkish: "Kardeşiz Kader") together with his manager and sent it to Yaşar Kekeva.
Kekeva, who likes Bergen, invited the artist to Istanbul.

The artist, who released his first professional longplay "İnsan Severse" in the Istanbul music industry with the music management of Burhan Bayar, became famous with "Acıların Kadını" which he did at the end of 1986.
Because it was very well received, the record company, in April 1987, awarded the album with a golden record and cassette for "the best selling Arabesque female artist of 1986".
In the same year, she appeared on the set of "Woman of Sorrows" with Yalçın Gülhan, Asuman Arsan and Meral Niron, which was written and directed by Ulkü Erakalın.
Having gained a great fan base, Bergen narrowly escaped a stabbing attack in Adana, where he went for a concert.

The singer, who once left the stage, released his albums "Onu da Yak Tanrım", "Sevgimin Bedeli" and "İstemiyorum" under the direction of the great masters Selami Şahin, Özer Şenay and Cengiz Tekin, in a row.

Bergen, who was officially divorced also from her husband in April 1989, returned to the stage in June 1989 with her last album "The Years Don't Forgive", which was released while she was still alive.
The artist, who started the promotion tours of the album that was received with great interest, was killed by being shot by her divorced wife in Pozanti, Adana on the night of 14-15 August 1989.
His corpse was buried in his hometown Mersin.
Bergen squeezed 29 years of life into 5 long plays, 11 cassettes, 129 songs, and one video film.

The claims that the artist, who signed arabesque with her distinctive and powerful voice, had become legendary were proven true when her album "My Young Life, which was released after her death, sold out on the first day.
Bergen's officially released studio albums:
1982 - I Have a Complaint LP (re-released as MC in 1986)
1983 - Kardeşiz Kader LP (reissued in 1985 and 1990 as a cassette tape.)

The Price of My Love (MC) 1988 (It was published on CD in 1999.)

1990 - My Youth Going MC (re-released in CD format in 1999.)
1990 - The Misfortune of the Poor Ends in the Grave MC (re-issued on CD in 1999).

Nazım Hikmet's 114th birthday was commemorated
The renowned Turkish poet Nazım Hikmet was commemorated on the 114th anniversary of his birth with an event called "I am glad that you were born, Nazım".
The event, organized by Konak Municipality, took place in the hall of the Güzelyalı Culture Center, named after the poet.
The activities included poetry and music recitals, and the famous poet's poems were read out by the theater and cinema actor Rüştü Asyalı.
In addition to that, Three Anatolian Music Bands accompanied Asyalı with their interpretations at the event.
Many art lovers accompanied the event on Nazım Hikmet.
Ali Seçkiner Alıcı, Erkoç Torun, Nedim Yıldız, Zeynep Göknur Yıldız and Ziya Özsökmenler are also among these names.
An event was organized by the Nazim Hikmet Culture and Art Foundation in Istanbul.

The Chairman of the Foundation, Rutkay Aziz, and the members, the daughter, son-in-law and grandson of Nâzım Hikmet's wife Vera Tulyakova, and the actor Tarık Akan, assembled in Tarabya for the event.
She will read poems with the slogan "To live like a tree, single and free / And brotherly like a forest" and she will leave carnations in the sea.
The event, arranged with the assistance of Sarıyer Municipality, will be accompanied by the songs of Nâzım Hikmet Choir.
Nazım Hikmet was born on January 15, 1902.
The verses of the world renowned poet Nazım Hikmet were translated into more than 50 languages.
He was arrested many times because of his political ideas and spent most of his adult life in prison or exile.
His poems have been translated into more than fifty languages, and his works have garnered many awards.
He passed away in June 3rd, 1963.
Nilüfer Municipality of Bursa did some special work for the 114th birthday of the world-famous poet Nâzım Hikmet.
While the works for the film "Bursa's Nazim", which tells about his 11 year Bursa Prison days, is going on, the municipality also issued the first personal stamp in Turkey's history for the poet.
Thus, the first personal postage stamp of Nazım Hikmet in Turkish history was put into circulation in cooperation with PTT.
This special coin, worth 1.40 TL, and the first day covers will be gifts to the guests at the gala on Thursday 14 January, at Nâzım Hikmet Kültürevi.

What are the benefits of steaming food?
The steam cooking technique, a technique that does not kill the vitamins and minerals in the food, is becoming increasingly popular.
Steaming, one of the most preferred cooking techniques in the Far East for centuries, strengthens metabolism and facilitates digestion.
This method completely eliminates problems such as indigestion and it also kills the bacteria and microbes found in foods.
The technique completely melts down the protein, cellulose and starch in food, making it softer.
Steam cooking at low pressure is conducted in containers or in a pot with the help of a steam machine.
When it is cooked at high pressure, the amount of water used and the cooking time are less.
The best example of this could be pressure cooking.
It is necessary to first wash the vegetables well, such as those that appear in diet menus and then wait for them to be well strained through the strainer.
A deep pot is filled with a third of water and a steam basket is placed inside.
The top of the pot is left half-open.
This allows the steam to leave the pot easily.
The oven fire was first brought to the highest level to cause the water to boil, then the oven fire was reduced to a lower level to get a constant heat.
Vegetables and food cooked in steam for about 10-15 minutes is checked by using a fork after completely cooking.
The cooked vegetables are taken out of the oven and placed onto plates to serve.
The appearance, color and smell of the food does not change in the steaming technique and thus, this method is healthy.
The food keeps its unique taste.
Thus the quality and taste of the food will be maintained.
In steam cooking, one of the most economical cooking methods, food loss is also kept to a minimum.
Steamed vegetables offer a satisfying feast with their livelier and more vivid look.
This method, which is frequently used especially in diet food, is preferred often since it is light.
