Attacks on journalists in Turkey have become commonplace.
Just ahead of Prime Minister Davutoğlu's visit to London next week, 25 prominent writers have sent a letter to British Prime Minister Cameron, signed jointly, about Turkey.
PEN members asked Cameron to raise the declining freedom of press and expression at his meeting with Davutoğlu.

Prominent writers of the United Kingdom sent a letter to Prime Minister David Cameron, asking him to raise the issue of Turkey's deteriorating press and freedom of expression during the upcoming visit of his counterpart Ahmet Davutoğlu to London next week.

The 25 authors, including the presidents of the Writers in Prison Committee of PEN International in Britain, Wales and Scotland, sent a letter expressing serious concerns over the unprecedented crackdown on freedom of expression in Turkey in their letter.

Pointing out that threats and physical attacks on journalists, writers, and publishers have become routine, the writers mentioned such examples as the attack on the Hürriyet newspaper offices, the raid on the Koza İpek Media Group, and the seizure of the group.

In a letter, PEN members including Tom Stoppard, Ali Smith, Ian Rankin and Elif Şafak. emphasize that 3 journalists, who work for the organization Vice News, were imprisoned, other journalists were prosecuted and the arrests of journalists continued.

The writers, who also noted that Can Dündar and Erdem Gül were arrested as part of the investigation phase of the MIT Trucks case, said that "It is important that journalists in Turkey perform their primary function in society and inform the public without any restrictions or censorship."
He noted that attacks against journalists, authors and publishers corrode the freedoms of all of Turkish society.
He said that journalists and writers were subjected to intimidation methods ranging from physical attacks because of the widespread "culture of immunity".

The writers point out that the number of Turkish citizens charged with the crime of 'insulting the president' has increased and that since Erdogan was elected in 2014, he has opened more cases of insult than the total number of all his predecessors combined.
Davutoğlu's words remained empty.
While it was emphasized that Prime Minister Davutoglu is one of the few government members who express support for press freedom, it was mentioned that these words did not convert into actions.
In the letter, it is stated "Therefore, Davutoğlu's visit to London creates an important opportunity to commit clearly to freedom of expression in Turkey."
The writers called on Cameron to ensure that his government respects Turkey's obligations on freedom of expression.
In the letter, the 25 writers whose signatures are there:

Monica Ali, Alan Bissett, William Boyd, Chris Brookmyre, Gillian Clarke, Drew Campbell (Chair of Scottish PEN), Fflur Dafydd, Stevie Davies, Menna Elfyn (Chair of Welsh PEN), Moris Farhi, Maureen Freely (Chair of English PEN), Richard Gwyn, Mark Haddon, David Hare, Eva Hoffman, Hari Kunzru, Robert Minhinnick, Blake Morrison, Neel Mukherjee, Ian Rankin, Elif Shafak, Owen Sheers, Ali Smith, Tom Stoppard, Sarah Waters.
Clashes spread to all neighbourhoods in Cizre, 2 children were killed in the courtyard of their house.
The curfew continues in Cizre, Şırnak province, which was declared on December 14.
From the day the embargo began, the silence of guns and explosions has been unsettling.
Residents leave the area, which is sometimes the scene of very violent clashes.
An explosive hit a house in Dağkapı neighbourhood, and two children aged 11 and 12 lost their lives.
The curfew was lifted in Cizre on the 33rd day.
The conflicts between the security forces and the PKK militants put the citizens in a tough position.

In the last 33 days, the people living in the quarters of Nur, Cudi, Sur and Yafes, which have trenches, have been leaving their quarters, as they have not been getting electricity or water for 33 days.
The fact that clashes are also occurring in neighbourhoods without trenches and barricades has forced people living here to leave.
Some of the citizens left the town with white flags on their vehicles, and others took what they could carry and moved to nearby towns and neighborhoods.
While clashes were continuing in neighborhoods with trenches and barricades, the residents here had moved to more central neighborhoods.
But recently, due to conflicts in these neighborhoods, residents also had to move out of these neighborhoods.

In one of these streets, Dağkapı Street, an uncle and his two children died as a result of a bomb hitting the door and splintering pieces hitting their bodies when they were in the yard of their house.
In a region with a high population density in Şah Mahallesi, three people were injured after an explosive was thrown at a building.
With the passage of more than a month since the ban, the need for cash money is getting more urgent for many citizens.
The residents of the district where all banks and ATMs were closed had to use their credit cards.
The citizens who do not have credit card, however, are in a difficult situation.
A lot of citizens migrated because they could not satisfy their food and medicine needs.
Those who remain in the district get by with aid from relatives and charitable Cizrelis.
In the district where only cases of emergency can go to a hospital, no medical intervention is available for those who suffer from toothache.

There has been no education in the district, where schools have been closed since the start of the operation on December 14.

At least 23 people were killed and 33 injured in a bomb and gun attack at a popular hotel and cafe among foreigners in the capital of West African country Burkina Faso, Ouagadougou.
In the operation conducted after the armed attack, 126 people who were taken hostage were rescued.
The minister of security, said that three of the attackers were made ineffective.
Armed and masked gunmen carried out a raid on a 147-room hotel and luxury restaurant in Burkina Faso's capital Ouagadougou Friday night, local time, around 8.00 pm.
French and UN forces based in the Gao region of Mali, five hours after the first attack, began the operation and the first news of the hostage rescue came.
President Roch Marc Christian Kabore has announced that 18 people from at least 23 different nations have been killed and 33 people have been injured in the incident.
The 126 people who were taken hostage in an operation after the attack were rescued.
